text:
Residents try to protect their river, by moving a chicken farm proposal off a FLOODPLAIN

...& then @EnvAgency:

'said it was up to local councils to decide where new developments such as poultry units should be set.'

...& here is the problem.

 https://t.co/cvGSZlXaZS
@AnabaticW @JuliaBradbury @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm @WMerciaPolice @HfdsCouncil This is not how you stop flooding.

@DENISEL37953929 @CraigBennett3 @NaturalEngland @EnvAgency @DefraGovUK @WildlifeTrusts We don‚Äôt know all the facts. Nor do you. But if approval was given by the EA & the Parish Council, the story is even worse than it appears, elevating an act of vandalism by an individual to one  of systematic incompetence, ignorance & misuse of power.

@GeoffDa84684078 @RichardCaddy @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm @WMerciaPolice @HfdsCouncil Coppicing riverbank trees helps stabilise banks. Ripping them out and leaving bare soil does not.

RT @Feargal_Sharkey: Curiouser and curiouser.

Farmer claims that he was given permission to dredge the riverbed and reprofile the bank by‚Ä¶

text:
@EnvAgency Save trees. Save environment. This Christmas please avoid cutting trees. Without them we can not survive.

We need trees for clean air.

#SayNoToChristmasTrees.
#SaveEnvironment
#Christmas2020

@UNEP @EnvAgency https://t.co/QK5Em9T7I3
@whiterosegreen @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm The flooding of Derwent Ings by Yorkshire Wildlife Trusts in the middle of nesting season is a ‚ÄòScottish play‚Äô incident too.

@Freedomofdoubt @farmerhudson @NaturalEngland @EnvAgency @ForestryComm Natural England wasn‚Äôt fit for purpose from inception. It‚Äôs raison d‚Äôetre was to see Nature Conservation downgraded in importance from the outset. That was clear by who they forced out from English Nature.

@NaturalEngland @EnvAgency @ForestryComm The irony. All the best staff saw the fiscal writing on the wall in ‚Äò06 with the dissolution of the legacy agencies and subsequent budget hacking. Many are top of their game in Europe now. Doing away with English Nature was criminal.
RT @KeasdenKate: 1/2: IF it is correct that this destruction was permitted by @EnvAgency, then they should only have permitted it having so‚Ä¶

text: @SteveCJjones @KeasdenKate @EnvAgency @DefraGovUK @TonyJuniper @NaturalEngland @pow_rebecca @ZacGoldsmith https://t.co/Itw42dl39N
RT @SteveCJjones: @AmiesPhilip @KeasdenKate @EnvAgency Well, this is really serious then. One can‚Äôt nod and wink at dredging, bank reprofil‚Ä¶

@SteveCJjones @EnvAgency I'm working off NE SSSI database. It says River Lugg SSSI overlaps with River Wye SAC so can't be sure re section affected - although works on any part of the river would affect areas downstream so assessment would have been required even if not inside SAC https://t.co/VQAmT7tsyB
RT @SteveCJjones: @AmiesPhilip @KeasdenKate @EnvAgency Clear case for prosecutions then. The Lugg dredging is a defining test case, @pow_re‚Ä¶

@fishfacejohnny @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Yes, he should have been aware it was a protected section of the river requiring permissions and permits to do works on. These works won‚Äôt have reduced flood risk likely will have increased it. He can and should be held responsible for the destruction.

@SteveCJjones @KeasdenKate @EnvAgency refused planning permission this year apparently https://t.co/S6ebsxxydp

@GarethTrewick @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Thanks I just saw an item about that. His village were frustrated by the @EnvAgency 's lack of action. Sad to see the trees go but - can we blame him?
@SteveCJjones @KeasdenKate @EnvAgency It is in SAC

@KeasdenKate Is impacted section itself SAC? If so the UK government itself could be prosecuted, potentially failing to conduct HRA of any consents and also under Regulation 3(2) for failing to take appropriate steps to avoid deterioration of a Natura 2000 Site. Nudges and winks by @EnvAgency

text: RT @river_usk: Lovin' this re-wiggling farmer, he can farm my banks anytime. We have heroics in these parts too with @Stumpupfortrees doing‚Ä¶
@EnvAgency Trees and their boughs fall in rivers and cause issues, just as falling leaves and other falling debris do
@fishfacejohnny @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm The landowner for ‚Äúflood risk and erosion control‚Äù according to a statement he has submitted to the local paper.

@ianrobertgilmo1 @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Works by rivers specifically this long, and protected as this is require flood risk permits. The EA will know if one was applied for and granted. Also permissions from NE to work on a sssi would be required. Contractors would have to submit a RAMS for both.
RT @KeasdenKate: 1/2: IF it is correct that this destruction was permitted by @EnvAgency, then they should only have permitted it having so‚Ä¶

1/2: IF it is correct that this destruction was permitted by @EnvAgency, then they should only have permitted it having sought the assent of @NaturalEngland (because it's a #SSSI) & it will also have required an assessment under the Habitats Regulations (because it's also an SAC) https://t.co/QdW8F8p2Js
